I would recommend teaching him through scratch programming language it is wonderful  particularly for young people. Basically, it is a graphical programming languages which means it teaches its students the programming concepts ( IF Statements, Boolean expressions, Variables .......etc ) by drag and drop method from pre customized items list to complete his/her task whatever it is a story, game or any other idea :) 

I am a certified Microsoft MCSD and before getting my hands dirty with the programming world I had more than 7 years of experience in children teaching and one major thing you have to consider is, getting your brother engaged and this through games and I think scratch will achieve this. I know what I am talking about and I am sure it will make a significant impact on your brother :) 

Just always keep in your mind Learning Is Fun !! and children learn better through Games !!

Here is the link https://scratch.mit.edu/

Wish you all the best and please feel free for any further clarification

Show him one hour code programmes

In my opinion Scratch is too basic for 12yrs old and might not give him interesting enough results soon. In my opinion, any simple PHP code that renders a simple webpage will let him feel like a hero already and will be so interesting for him, although he might develop bad programming habits so quickly that way!

Excuse me Mohammed, I do not agree with you ! and this is for three reasons :

1) I am not sure how did you conclude that Scratch is too basic for a 12 years old kid !! just for your information, Scratch is used to expose   students into programming in the art of programming and computer science course - Harvard university - you can check their website, this course is for free and it is very enjoyable  by the way :)  last but not least in this point, the average age in this program ( introduction to the art of programming and computer science is about 18 years as no one is less than 16 years old but there are some who are older !!)  keeping in mind that they are native speaker and they are some how will not have any problems dealing with any materials in their mother tongue language compared to our little brother situation :)  

2) Based on my experience ( Educating Children ) they learn through games and graphical interfaces much faster more than any other methods.

3) As for me the first step I would try to make with any young children is to expose him to a topic step by step and I wonder really how you would educate a kid 12 years old a PHP code !!

I have browsed the entire internet for programming schools all over the world to see how they teach young adults ( up to 16-18 years  ) programming and all of they recommended scratch and a similar couple languages I do not remember their names. 

You look very smart software engineer :) but please keep in mind that people have different mentalities abilities and this has to be considered :) especially for young ages

I agree with Mohamed Nasif that kids learn faster if it's about building a game. Inspired to build a game like Red Alert, I picked up a 3d modeling course before realizing that I need to learn coding first to build a game, and that red alert 2 was 2d in the first place :D.

As for kids learning PHP, I actually saw lynda.com offering a course on that topic! http://www.lynda.com/PHP-tutorials/Teach-Kids-Programming-PHP/142020-2.html

As much as I would love to see my little 16 year old sister learn PHP, I can't even get her excited about the idea at all, and would love to see how I could. On the other hand, something like scratch might seem more interesting...

In my own opinion getting someone excited about programming is very difficult at the first place if he/she doesn't have any interest at all already. I am considering the step just after getting his interest. I have meet a 16yr old boy who was participating in a regional Google+ hackathon and using PHP and I had the honor to discuss with him and his father how he ended up there! One major idea, that the father didn't even 'get him excited about the idea', rather the boy himself had enough initial interest to mimic websites and to build his own website. On the other hand, the young father was just trying so hard to provide him all available resources and exposing him to different opportunities - and that hackathon was one of them. Another model I witnessed is allowing kids to use robots to visualize their programs. In that model, kids got more excited when they saw the robot following the simple logic they programmed.
I am not against Scratch itself, but I saw many boys in that age who weren't really interested in the results they get using it. Yet it will be nice to start with and observe the reactions, and if you feel your brother started to lose interest then introduce the next step to him.
Another more interesting app in my opinion in that case would be MIT App Inventor http://appinventor.mit.edu/. The main difference, is that at least you can see the results on a mobile phone, which would be more interesting.

Mohamed Hagras try to watch movies without reading subtitles, also watch lots of technical videos and english and read a lot of books. Always have a dictionary at hand, try to learn 10 new words every day with their meaning and use in sentences. It is like programmingm just requires practice. The idea is, I only have English on my keyboard and I need to use something like Yamli.com to write in Arabic, On Arabic keyboards my typing is slow.  It is not a matter of which is better, Also note, I knwo some people who joined Microsoft because they knew french and they weren't even that technical, knowing French or Spanish could give you a better chance of joining MS than being a tech Guru, even if you are just average BTW.
